metadata.title: PathOS Training Session: Exploring the Economic Impact of Open Science
metadata.description:
Presentation from the Exploring the Economic Impact of Open Science webinar, part of the PathOS training series.

On March 28, 2025, we hosted an insightful webinar on the Economic Impact of Open Science, focusing on how Open Science fosters economic growth and innovation, particularly within the life sciences sector. 

The session featured experts Lena Tsipouri (OPIX) and Despoina Sousoni (ELIXIR), who presented key findings from a scoping review and a detailed case study on the use of open bioinformatics resources by industry. The case study highlighted how these resources play a crucial role in driving innovation and generating economic benefits.

Recording is aviliable here. 

Learn more about PathOS Training here.

data.title: PathOS Training Session: Exploring the Economic Impact of Open Science

metadata.title: Rethinking the Role of Value-Added Industries for Invasive Trees in South Africa
metadata.description: Invasive alien trees are a threat to sustainable development in South Africa due to their rapid propagation and negative impacts on water availability, fire risks, land productivity, and biodiversity conservation. Despite the ambitious three decades-long governmental Working for Water programme to clear and restore land, the problem remains. This paper questions the proposition that value-added industries can contribute to its resolution by providing value to the biomass and supporting upscaled control efforts with private investments. Their financial feasibility remains largely theoretical as most studies resort to ex ante assessments untested on the ground and are misleading due to the mix of tangible financial flows and hypothetical environmental benefits. Assumed perverse effects with further propagation remain theoretical or rest on anecdotical evidence. It is suggested that value-added industries and particularly bioenergy hold potential but require a more conducive policy environment. Three priorities are identified: an incentives framework that recognises environmental (dis)services and clarifies potential net carbon gains depending on the accounting system; the provision of updated information to the private sector on resource availability with improved coordination between investors and public programs in charge of land clearing; and innovative supply chain models with improved logistics. Thinking outside the box would help and novel land management options could be considered with natural regrowth and rotations in non-strategic sites, or crop substitution to sustain value chains – which would necessitate strict management rules in exchange for greater flexibility in resource accessibility. Overall, value-added industries for invasive trees encompass climate change adaptation and mitigation and their feasibility depends on their articulation.
keywords: ALIEN PLANTS; BIOENERGY; ENERGY TRANSITION; RESTORATION; VALUE-ADDED INDUSTRY

dates.description: Invasive alien trees are a threat to sustainable development in South Africa due to their rapid propagation and negative impacts on water availability, fire risks, land productivity, and biodiversity conservation. Despite the ambitious three decades-long governmental Working for Water programme to clear and restore land, the problem remains. This paper questions the proposition that value-added industries can contribute to its resolution by providing value to the biomass and supporting upscaled control efforts with private investments. Their financial feasibility remains largely theoretical as most studies resort to ex ante assessments untested on the ground and are misleading due to the mix of tangible financial flows and hypothetical environmental benefits. Assumed perverse effects with further propagation remain theoretical or rest on anecdotical evidence. It is suggested that value-added industries and particularly bioenergy hold potential but require a more conducive policy environment. Three priorities are identified: an incentives framework that recognises environmental (dis)services and clarifies potential net carbon gains depending on the accounting system; the provision of updated information to the private sector on resource availability with improved coordination between investors and public programs in charge of land clearing; and innovative supply chain models with improved logistics. Thinking outside the box would help and novel land management options could be considered with natural regrowth and rotations in non-strategic sites, or crop substitution to sustain value chains – which would necessitate strict management rules in exchange for greater flexibility in resource accessibility. Overall, value-added industries for invasive trees encompass climate change adaptation and mitigation and their feasibility depends on their articulation.

references: Pirard, R. (2023). Rethinking the role of value-added industries for invasive trees in South Africa. *International Forestry Review*, 25(2), 223–243. https://doi.org/10.1505/146554823837244428

metadata.title: Adverse Outcome Pathway Wiki RDF
metadata.description: This dataset is the RDF generated from the AOP-Wiki data release (aopwiki.org/downloads). It was generated using a Jupyter notebook that is available on GitHub (github.com/marvinm2/AOPWikiRDF), and the process and additional description of the RDF have been published (doi.org/10.1089/aivt.2021.0010).

metadata.title: Quantum-Resonance Induced Biostasis- Mapping Cryptobiosis Through ETSTM for Human Application.
metadata.description:
This research paper, “Quantum-Resonance Induced Biostasis: Mapping Cryptobiosis Through ETSTM for Human Application,” explores the integration of cutting-edge methodologies, including Entanglement to Space-Time Mapping (ETSTM), Helicopter AI, Automatic Toggling Intelligence (ATI), and Dual Validation System (DVS), to understand and replicate cryptobiosis for human biology. Cryptobiosis is the state of suspended animation observed in organisms such as nematodes and tardigrades, which enables survival under extreme environmental conditions like dehydration, freezing, and radiation.

 

This paper delves into the quantum-resonance mechanisms that sustain life in cryptobiotic organisms and investigates how these principles could be adapted to human biology. By utilizing AI systems for data-driven exploration and hypothesis testing, the paper proposes novel methods for inducing metabolic suspension, biochemical stabilization, genetic adaptation, and altered states of consciousness in humans. The potential applications of this research span fields such as medicine (for trauma and critical care), space exploration (long-duration hibernation), and anti-aging.

 

With the integration of ETSTM and AI systems, this work offers a transformative framework for biostasis research, promising a paradigm shift in how we understand life suspension and its potential for human application.

dates.description: This work offers a transformative framework for biostasis research, promising a paradigm shift in how we understand life suspension and its potential for human application.

references: 1. Coupland, S. J. (2025). ETSTM – Revolutionizing FX Trading with Liquidity Mapping and AI Predictive Models. 10.5281/zenodo.15066908 2. Coupland, S. J. (2025). Reconnecting Ancient Knowledge with Modern Quantum Consciousness- A Unified Resonance Framework Approach. 10.5281/zenodo.15117358 3. Emoto, M. (2004). The Hidden Messages in Water. Atria Books. 4. Einstein, A., Rosen, N. (1935). The Particle Problem in Quantum Mechanics. Physical Review, 48(3), 366-368. 5. Penrose, R. (1994). Shadows of the Mind: A Search for the Missing Science of Consciousness. Oxford University Press. 6. Schrödinger, E. (1944). What is Life? The Physical Aspect of the Living Cell. Cambridge University Press. 7. Tarter, J., & Clark, A. (2018). Quantum Mechanics and the Search for Extraterrestrial Life. Journal of Astrobiology, 19(3), 150-171. 8. Zohar, D., & Marshall, I. (2000). The Quantum Self: Human Nature and Consciousness Defined by the New Physics. Quill.

metadata.title: Reconnecting Ancient Knowledge with Modern Quantum Consciousness- A Unified Resonance Framework Approach.
metadata.description: This paper explores the integration of ancient technologies and modern quantum theories to propose a new paradigm for understanding consciousness, biostasis, and reincarnation. It suggests that ancient civilizations may have harnessed resonance-based principles to preserve consciousness and enable biostasis, potentially through the construction of resonance chambers or quantum hubs. Using AI-driven analysis and quantum simulations, we aim to uncover hidden patterns within ancient sites like the pyramids and stone spheres, revealing a deeper connection between ancient wisdom and modern scientific discoveries

dates.description: Explores the integration of ancient technologies and modern quantum theories to propose a new paradigm for understanding consciousness, biostasis, and reincarnation.

metadata.title: Deep Learning Models for Malware Family Detection
metadata.description: Malware attacks have been rising and the challenge in detection and mitigation have fallen short to counter the threats. The advances in artificial intelligence have not yielded in early detection of malware and its variants. Malware detection becomes critical. Our work leverages on the biology-inspired analysis of malware trace sequences and clustering based on similarity computation of malware traces. The malware traces extracted from the community detection algorithms are assumed to represent malware families precisely. The extracted traces are used in the deep learning framework for prediction of malware families. In this work, deep learning models are evaluated and experimental results are presented. The results elucidate the deep learning framework for malware family detection.
references: Dunn, C., & Krishnendu, G. (2024). Fingerprinting of Malware Families Under Uncertainty. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.10674537

data.title: Deep Learning Models for Malware Family Detection
